turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments first this morning in No. 1844, City of Mobile against Bolden and the consolidated case of Williams against Brown.
Mr. Rhyne, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
This case presents a question of whether the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment requires the abolition of the Mobile commission form of government elected at large.
This is the first case involving a state or a local government where the entire form of government, not just the manner of its election, has been held unconstitutional.
Mobile is one-third black.
The District Court held that only the abolition of the commission form of government in its entirety could "provide blacks a realistic opportunity to elect blacks to the city governing board."
The District Court also held that equal opportunity included the election of representatives of their choice.

Now, the ultimate issue in this case is whether the only way to satisfy the Constitutional requirement of equal protection -- or equal participation in the voting processes of a government is by electing a black to the Mobile governing body.

Now, the District Court held that while it was making all of the findings about various subjects that I just mentioned, that blacks did not participate effectively, and we say this is a clearly erroneous error because the record establishes beyond question that in every contested election in the City of Mobile, and the last one was in 1973, the black vote is decisive.
In 1973, for example, Commissioner Greenough ran against Commissioner Bailey, who had defeated Commissioner Langan, who had been elected and re-elected 16 years with black support.
And in the first election he received only 15% of the black vote.
In the runoff he received 43 and not elected.

And as we state and quote on pages 9 and 10 of our brief, the judge is questioning Reverend Hope, who is the black president of the Non-Partisan Voters League, and he asked him, "Isn't it a fact that the black vote in the Greenough race was the difference, and in the Mims race, the other commissioner?”
And he said, "Yes."

And then in addition to that, I would point out to the Court that Commissioner Doyle had no opposition but he testified that when he first ran, that he went to the Non-Partisan Voters League, which is the only slating organization in Mobile and it's black.
And he was screened by them and they endorsed him.
And each one of these appellants have gone to that league and received its endorsement after being screened by them.
And so the blacks do participate very vigorously in the electoral processes of Mobile.
And so I say that where the elections are -- are non-partisan and where each of the appellants go and seek the black vote, and where it's decisive, it cannot be said to be submerged or diluted.

Now, the Reverend Hope, when he was testifying in his final statement that we quote on page 10, makes just one sentence which I would like to quote to the Court because I think it's important, because he was talking about the fact that he was speaking for the entire League, which is all -- all black and the most important slating organization.

He said, "They feel the candidates they have elected" -- now these are the three appellants who are here, and by "they" he means the Non-Partisan Voting League -- "have done a very good job along that line of -- of serving blacks."

And over and over again this record is full of instances in which blacks testified that when they supported these appellants, they went down to City Hall and they asked for what they wanted, and if it was possible in law and money, they got it.

And I'm not going to read the long list, but I can say this, eight, the only eight of the witnesses of the plaintiffs who were asked if they'd been down to City Hall, and under this open door policy that's maintained by these commissioners who exercise dual functions under the commission form of government, they have both legislative and executive powers so they can in effect do it all.
They -- if they tell one of these blacks, "We're -- you're going to get a pavement."
"You're going to get this."
They get it because they have the power to do it.

And so the fact that they not only take part in the entire voting process from registration all the way through but they then in effect collect on their political obligations shows that they play an extremely important part in the political processes of Mobile.
Now, we had one time in 1973 where three blacks ran and those three blacks didn't carry the black wards.

Now, as witness Alexander, Dan Alexander who is a witness for the plaintiff, testified in his testimony for the plaintiff, an election for a commissioner and an election for the school board are two entirely different things.
When you run for the school board, and Dan Alexander is a member of the school board, you talk about what you can do for the school kids and it's county-wide.
When you run for commissioner, you talk about what a good businessman or woman you are because the commission form of government is supposed to elect businessmen to run cities.

That's why it came into existence and that's why over and over again when they've had referendums in Mobile -- well, they've had them in 1963 and 1973, according to -- to the record, the people have overwhelmingly supported this businessman form of local government.
Now, the Court below held that the intent that was important here was not the intent of the three defendants but the intent of the legislature.
Now, the legislature is not a defendant here.
No state official is a defendant.
And they go on and on and on talking about bills that have gone up to Montgomery to change the form of government.
And when you're talking about legislative intent you're talking about a very nebulous thing.

But in their supplemental brief they cited the fact that Senator Buskey, a black Senator, had introduced a bill to give the people of Mobile a chance to vote on another referendum about changing its government and they go on and on about how the fact that that bill went through the House and then lost in the Senate.
What they don't tell you is this, that that bill reached the Senate on its 28th legislative day.
It got its first reading that very day which is very unprecedented.
It got its second reading, and this is on page 10 and 11 that they discuss this, its second reading on the 29th legislative day.
And then it got lost in the usual pile-up of bills in State legislatures on that last day.
The thing that -- that interests me is that the black Senator from Mobile, according to the journal, had absolutely nothing to say.
The bill died.
Now -- but again, it was a -- going to give the people of Mobile a chance to have a referendum.

So I urge upon the Court that the relevant intent that you're going to consider intent is that of the three defendants, the three commissioners that are before you, and you can't find in this record, if you read it from beginning to end, any instance in which they who must have the votes of the blacks to win have discriminated against the blacks.
The black's votes are equally counted.
They have an open door policy.
They see them.

And as I say, the only eight witnesses of the plaintiff who were asked testified unequivocally that when they went to City Hall, they saw the appellants and they got what they went for if it was legally or financially possible.
And so it's not the state intent that's so important here.
It is the intent of these three appellants.
If it was the state intent, why don't they have the state here?

Yet the very basis of the District Court decisions and the very basis of the Appellate Court decision is the inference that they draw from the fact that no black, and the District Court repeats this three times, has ever won a seat as commissioner of Mobile.
He doesn't add the next part of it which is that no qualified blacks ever run.
And the other inference they draw is that state inaction is circumstantial evidence of invidious intent against what?
These three appellants?
What do they have to do with the -- the state legislature's intent?
And it's the most nebulous, hardest thing to get at in the whole world.
It's like asking Barry Goldwater what Senator McGovern's intent was on a bill.
I -- I don't believe that the relevant intent is that of the state legislature but the relevant intent is that of the appellant commissioners.
They're the only defendants.
They're the only ones that are before this Court.
And so I urge indeed that they have never been shown to have a racial purpose.
They have been shown over and over again to be very sensitive to the needs of blacks.

And there is no racial purpose that can be attributed to them in any way or how can they get over and over the endorsement of the blacks and how can they, when these only three blacks ran, carry even the black wards?

So another point that I would make is that the Court of Appeals held that there was a very strong city governmental intent in at-large elections in Mobile because they were brought in to wipe out ward healing, corrupt government, and that this -- this government has served Mobile well for 68 years without any charges of corruption or -- or anything else.
And that is the good government that they're asking this Court to uphold the abolition of.
Now, the failure of the court below to find this -- that in this record over and over again that the blacks are such an important element of the political processes.
They get on the stand and they brag about how important they are.
Wiley Bolden said, “Sure, they follow the pink sheet.”
That the pink sheet is the one that has the names of the people that the blacks have endorsed.
And when the blacks ran, they endorsed some of the blacks, but they also endorsed the whites and the appellants.

So I urge upon you that the intent that is important is the intent of these appellants that they have done absolutely nothing that can be called on this record invidious discrimination.No black has ever lost an election in Mobile because of polarized voting.

And if you're going to draw inferences, why do you have to stop -- they -- they point to Montgomery, they point to Birmingham where tomorrow we may learn something because the men who got more votes than I think all three candidates, white candidates, for mayor is up for the final vote.
I think he got 30-something-thousand and the other three got 30-something-thousand.
But, look at Atlanta.
Look at New Orleans.
Look at Detroit.
Look at Newark.
And my prime example of all and -- because I'm leaving to go out there tomorrow, is Los Angeles.
Look at Bradley.
Bradley ran when only 17% of the people of Los Angeles were black.
He was defeated the first time around but he pulled himself up and ran again and he's been elected over and over and over again.

But yet in here, they talk about discouragement as being the reason that no qualified black has ran in Mobile even though they have equal opportunity, equal access, equal everything, and all they need is a qualified candidate.
Now, it's true that on the record there was some dispute about whether qualified blacks could win.
The interesting thing to me was is the judge was working over Mr. Langan, who had won for 16 years straight and then the blacks turned against him so he lost.
He was trying to get him to say that no black could be elected.
And he said, "Well, it depends on the person."
And I think that's true.
I think that the color of a man, the color of a woman, doesn't count in politics any more, it's their qualifications.
And this commission form of government, above all emphasizes, as Dan Alexander said, the business capacity of those who want to be commissioners.
Another aspect of this is, there are enormous differences between a city and a state.
I don't think that your decisions that relate to state governments really apply here.
If you wipe out a multi-member state district, it doesn't change overall the state government.

If you wipe out the commission form of government in Mobile, you disestablish the whole government and bring in a whole -- whole new government, a mayor and nine councilmen and the councilmen meet once a week and get $50 for a meeting, they can only talk to the mayor, they're not allowed to talk to the employees.
And so the blacks really are diluted by that order because now they can go down and see any one of the commissioners and get anything they want, talk to the head man, because they see them all.
And under the Court's order they have to go down and see the mayor and wait in line, and they don't have the clout under the order that they have now.
So --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Under the remedy decreed by the District Court and affirmed by the Court of Appeals, predictably there would be a minority of Negroes in the City Council, wouldn't there?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: It looks like there would be three, yes.
And so, now, Reverend Hope, for example, would have one of those who he could go see and he would go down to City Hall.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They'd be a minority?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: And so now, as the situation is, according to his testimony, he goes down and sees one of the commissioners directly, and the commissioner can order anything.
And so they can do it all.
So actually they're being diluted.
Now, the -- we cite in our brief the comments about the political scientists have made about this.
They say that the form of government is -- local government is peculiarly something for the people of the locality.
I think I've probably read more charters and I don't mean to brag about it, than any other man alive, because I've lived my life here.
I once went out to -- to Denver and met Quigg Newton and people when they were redoing the Denver thing, and I took a stack of charters.
I can tell you that there is not a single city charter that is identical with any other.
They are always adapted to the needs of that locality.
And I'm not sure if the courts are political scientists enough to tell local governments what kind of government is good for them.
But I come back to the point I mentioned below already, and I want to emphasize it because I think it's important.
Here, we have a good government being wiped out based on inferences and circumstantial evidence and -- as against the record of the election of qualified blacks nationwide.
To me it just doesn't stand up, and to me, the Constitutional requirement is full participation in the political process, not a guarantee of end result.

Now, we talk about proportional representation of a race, and you've said you're never going to grant that.I once went out to Cincinnati and talked to Mayor Seasongood for half a day trying to understand proportional representation.
I never did.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: After he have to run under it, don't he?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: I -- I suppose that you did.
But all of this, thousand over ten and all that kind of stuff kind of left me.
Now -- so I conclude by simply saying that this case is enormously important not just to Mobile but to the 67% of cities throughout the nation that elect at large.
Look at the New England town meeting.
There's a --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Rhyne, before you -- before you conclude, in your -- earlier in your argument you suggested that the people whose intent would be most relevant would be the intent of the three commissioners, the defendants.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: How do you read the District Court findings and the Court of Appeals opinion?
Whose intent do you think those courts were talking about?
The opinions are a little bit unclear to me.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: They were talking about the intent of the legislature.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You think it's definitely the intent of the legislature?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Oh, yes.
They pinned everything on the intent of the legislature.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Because some of the material under the Zimmer factors wouldn't really bear on the intent of the legislators very much and they seem to rely on those factors.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Well, I haven't said anything about some of the Zimmer factors, the service factors.
There are other remedies for that and I just don't think they belong in a voting rights case and so I haven't gone into that.

And -- but there's no question but what both courts looked to the intent of the legislature, not the intent of these appellants, because if you look to the intent of the three defendants here, it's so overwhelmingly in favor of the blacks.
There's nothing on the other side.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Rhyne, before you sit down, you've indicated in your oral argument and also I think in your briefs that it's your position that only the Fourteenth Amendment is involved in this case and only the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Your Brothers talk about the Voting Rights Act of 1965 as well as the Fifteenth Amendment, in addition to the Fourteenth Amendment.
I gather you think they're --

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Well, with respect to the Voting Rights Act, I think that there has been no change here and the footnote in Circuit Court of Appeals, footnote 14 where they say it's problematic, they've never heard of it being applied this way in a dilution case.
I don't believe the Voting Rights Act has any application whatever.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was that part of the -- was that included as a ground of the cause of action in the complaint?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: It was.
And if they didn't like the way it was ruled on there they could have appealed and didn't so I don't think it's before this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And how about the Fifteenth Amendment?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: The Fifteenth Amendment, the District Court really didn't say anything about the Court of Appeals, said it required intent, so you -- they really brought it down to about the same thing as -- as the Fourteenth Amendment.
And again, they didn't appeal from that ruling and so I don't think it's before the Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course they -- if the judgment can be supported on the basis of either the statute or the Fifteenth Amendment I suppose they're entitled to support it.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Well, I think that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On those grounds, on either of those grounds.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: My answer would be that it cannot be on the facts in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The decision of the District Court and the Court of Appeals, as you understand them were grounded on the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: That's right, entirely.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Blacksher.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
There are really only two issues that this Court must address in this case.
The first is whether the case should be decided on the basis of the statute, the Voting Rights Act, or whether it should be decided on the basis of the Constitution.

And the second issue is whether this Court will affirm and leave undisturbed the findings of two courts below that the at-large election system in Mobile, Alabama is maintained for invidiously discriminatory reasons.

We believe that particularly in light of the decisions of this Court in the last term, Cannon versus University of Chicago in particular, that the conclusion that there is a private cause of action under Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is inescapable.
Under the facts of Cort versus Ash, there is virtually no difference between the application of that case to Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act and Title 9 of the Education Amendments.
That has been briefed and I will not go to -- into it in further detail.

With respect to the findings of fact that there is an invidious purpose in the maintenance of this election system, we believe, as we have said in the supplemental brief, that Columbus and Dayton and indeed, Personnel Administrator of Massachusetts against Feeney, virtually require this Court, following the same principles, to affirm the findings of the District Court and the Court of Appeals that the at-large election system first put into effect in 1911 has not been changed, notwithstanding attempts to do so, because of, not in spite of but because of, the knowledge that the at-large system prevents blacks from having their electoral choices registered in the election process.
Now, with respect to the remedy --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Blacksher, before you get to remedy, whose intent are we talking about?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We're talking about the legislators' intent.

We believe if we correctly read Washington versus Davis and Arlington versus Metropolitan Housing Authority, if we correctly read -- read those cases we are talking about the lawmakers' intent if we are investigating the question of invidious purpose behind particular legislation.

If we are talking about the intent of the people who operate the statute then we've got what I suppose would be a Yick Wo versus Hopkins type of -- of case in -- in which case we would shift our gaze to the -- and scrutiny to the actions of the -- of the people who were actually operating the election system.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: And not --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Blacksher, forgive me if I've interrupted your answer to Justice Stevens' question.
I wasn't sure whether you were finished or not.

If -- if you're right that the judgment should be affirmed here because blacks are not being permitted to have their impact felt in the electoral -- in the electoral process, how far out can that process be -- line of reasoning be extended under your theory?
How many other groups can claim that they were discriminated against by the state legislature because the state legislature just didn't happen to like that particular group?
I mean Catholics, Jews?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I think Mr. Justice Rehnquist that that question has to be answered in the context of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

And this Court first must look to the question whether or not the judgments below must be sustained on the basis of the Voting Rights Act, which specifically addresses race or the Fifteenth Amendment in the cases decided under it.
I believe that for the purposes of this case it's important to recall that the dilution principle did not derive Constitutionally from the principle of one person, one vote.
Racial abridgement -- the abridgment of voting rights on the basis of race did not derive from the Fourteenth Amendment principles of a full and effective vote in one person, one vote.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where did it derive from?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: It derived from the Constitution of the United States, the Fifteenth Amendment and the statutes enacted under it.

What I wanted to point out was that in Reynolds versus Sims, this Court had to look to the Fifteenth Amendment and to the cases decided under it, specifically Lane versus William -- Wilson, Gomillion versus Lightfoot, Brown versus the Board, to find in the Equal Protection Clause a principle that says that there is a full and effective vote for other classes of people.
And it was on the basis of that analogy or that juxtaposition of the Fifteenth Amendment to the Fourteenth that there was ever developed a one person, one vote principle.

In fact, I think it's interesting to note that -- that the -- the fundamental disagreement that Justice Stewart had with the Reynolds case all through the years has been that it was too simplistic, sixth grade arithmetic.
And did not take into account the realities of the political process to which the Constitution must address itself.
For example, and I -- I cite -- I quote here, if the Court will indulge me momentarily from -- from Justice Stewart's dissent in Lucas versus the Colorado Assembly.

"I could not join in the fabrication of a Constitutional mandate which imports and forever freezes one theory of political thought into our Constitution and denies to every State any opportunity for enlightened and progressive innovation in the design of its democratic institutions so as to accommodate within a system of representative government the interests and aspirations of diverse groups of people without subjecting any group or class to absolute domination by geographically concentrated or highly organized majority."

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you think that helps you?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I believe it does Justice Stewart because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I think it would, rather a -- an expression of unwillingness to join in forcing a state to do anything, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I confess that in that -- in that particular decision, your attention was directed to the prerogatives of the state legislature not to what the Constitution requires.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I said the Constitution didn't require that.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: You said the Constitution did not require the imposition of strict population, that one person --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And do you think it follows that the Constitution does require something else?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I believe the Constitution does require that the right of persons to vote not be abridged on the basis of race.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well no, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That much we know.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What part of the Constitution are you relying on when you say that?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: The Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This case was decided on the basis of the Fourteenth Amendment, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: This case was decided on the basis of the Fourteenth and the Fifteenth Amendments in the judgment of the Court of Appeals below.

And we relied from the beginning on the Voting Rights Act which was discussed earlier as another statutory as the first cause of action that the Court ought to approach which of course is decided under the enforcement provision of the Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, the -- the Voting Rights Act, that is the section with which this Court has dealt primarily has to do with a -- a change in the method of -- in some scheme or device or some change in the -- in the method of election.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That is Section 5 of the Act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And you rely on Section 2, is it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We rely on Section 2, which is the general provision of the Voting Rights Act which extends substantive rights to voters.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But doesn't purport to confer any private cause of action, does it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We believe that it does.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it doesn't -- doesn't explicitly do so, does it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: It does not explicitly do so any more than Title 9 of the education amendments did.

But all of the elements including an expression of understanding on the part of the Congress that it does confer a private cause of action on private individuals as expressed in debates on the floor, as expressed in the -- in the enactment of a -- an attorney's fee provision.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The District Court and the Court of Appeals didn't rely on the Voting Rights Act, did it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: In its motion to dismiss --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Could they?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: -- early in the case, it held that we did have a cause of action.
When it wrote, at the end of the case, it did not even address this -- the -- the Voting Rights Act issue.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the Court of Appeals mentioned it in a footnote, I think, didn't they?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: In a footnote it said, we're going to have to reach the Constitutional issue anyway because we are -- we've got Nevett versus Sides with us today.
And so we're not going to -- to go into the knotty -- what we see as a knotty question of whether there's a private cause of action (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So if we agree that that was a knotty question, I suppose it would be our duty to remand it to the Court of Appeals if we thought that was a dispositive?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: There's a possibility.
In the -- in the Beazer case last term, the possibility of remanding it was objected and the Court went ahead and reached the statutory issue first at -- at this juncture.

And we believe that since what we are talking about is not a review of the factual circumstances in light of the statutory standards, that it makes little sense for this Court to remand which is essentially a legal question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But in any event Mr. Blacksher, when I interrupted you with my question, you were relying on the Constitution, and --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: From --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- it's the Fifteenth Amendment, not the Fourteenth, upon which you rely?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Oh, what we're --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because Reynolds versus Sims and it's all those related cases involve the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I was responding to Justice Rehnquist in this vein, we have understood --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) and that was a Fourteenth Amendment case?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: It was and we rely on the Fourteenth Amendment as well as the Fifteenth Amendment and the Voting Rights Act.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But what -- what result do you get in reliance on the amendments you've recited to Justice Stewart and the statutes in respect to -- my question is to who, other than blacks can make this same claim that although they're allowed to vote there are -- they are -- their representation is diluted because of the way of the district -- the districting goes, even though one man, one vote is complied with?
I take it from your referral to Yick Wo that Asian Americans could rely on it.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We certainly believe they could, if they can show that they've been treated the way the black folks have been treated in Mobile.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And where -- where -- and that's a statutory showing?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That would be our understanding of the Reynolds principle under the Fourteenth Amendment.
But the point I was trying to make and I confess I got into it a little bit obliquely is this.

We understand the argument of the appellants in this case to be that if this Court determines that the election system in Mobile satisfies the one person, one vote principle, you ought to let it alone.
That there ought not be any further federal inquiry or intervention into the actual workings of the political process to determine whether or not blacks' rights are nevertheless being abridged.
And I am simply pointing out that that's letting the tail wag the Constitutional dog.
That if -- if there is a one person, one vote principle it is because the Constitution spoke first to the equal rights and to the voting rights of black people.

And whatever -- whatever rights other groups may have under the Fourteenth Amendment principles developed under Reynolds, surely the important rights of blacks which the Civil War Amendment was designed to protect cannot be forgotten in the shuffle.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you think those rights are denied when you have an at-large election for the governor of the State of Alabama, for example?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: No, sir, because the governor is one office and it is not a representative office in the nature of a legislature or one --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well they -- these people are -- have legislative duties but they also have executive and administrative duties, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is not a pure legislature.
This is not representative democracy.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Mr. Justice Stewart, we are not attacking majority rule.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: We are simply seeking on behalf of the black people of Mobile the opportunity to participate --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How about in the State of Alabama generally, when they elect the governor?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I beg your pardon, sir?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How about -- what proportion of the State of Alabama are -- are Negro voters?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Approximately between -- approximately 30% of the -- or 35%.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Has there ever been a Negro governor of Alabama?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: There has never been a black governor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Wouldn't the same Constitutional claim be assertable in that situation?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We say it does not.
As I say, it has to do with the nature of the -- of the body that we're talking about.

Where more than one person is elected for the purpose of representing diverse interests in the community, as in -- to use your language, there -- there would be no need to have three commissioners for the city commission.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, each -- each has a different set of duties, doesn't he?
Isn't one finance and the other safety, or something and the other?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: He does by virtue of statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: At one time before 1965 there was not a statutory requirement that they divide up those duties.
That was something that was put into the law in 1965.
It's something by the way that the 1979 bill that Mr. Rhyne was talking about would have taken out.
It would have allowed the commission --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it -- it is true now, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: It is true now.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And he's the executive of the City of Mobile?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who is?
That's the question.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: The three commissioners --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: -- and the mayor.
The mayor is the nominal chief executive of the -- of the city and that's a rotating position among the three commissioners.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And -- but the three commissioners have the executive power, do they not?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: They do -- they have the executive power.
They had the legislative power.
They had the administrative power and to some extent the judicial power.
Although we have a Municipal Court that exercises most of the judicial power of the city.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How do you distinguish the executive functions of the commissioners and particularly of the one who is the mayor from the executive functions of the governor of a state?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I don't think that there is any need to distinguish those executive functions, Chief Justice Burger.
I believe that with respect to the executive functions there's no reason to say that blacks must have an equal opportunity to elect a person in every executive office or every executive department.
What they do or what they are entitled to is a right to share fairly and effectively in the administrative and legislative group determinations that government carries out in Mobile.
I would like to point out the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What percentage -- what percentage -- does this record show what percentage of the Negro voters actually vote?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: The latest -- the latest turnout figures that we were able to come up with would indicate that black voter registration was around 65% and that black turnout was something like -- well, is about the same as whites in -- in elections where there were black candidates and less than whites.
And when it was a good as the white turnout it was around 36-40%.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But if all of the Negroes registered and all of them voted, isn't it likely that they could on this record elect at least one commissioner?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Not in the city.
That -- that was a fact that the Court found for the plaintiffs.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes, I know they found it, but does this -- did they find it with respect to that proposition that if every Negro eligible to register did register and every registered Negro voter Negro voter voted, did they make a finding on that?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Although it was not cast in those terms, the court's language can be read to include that implication which was discussed during the trial.
And that -- I think the Court says there's no reasonable opportunity for blacks to have their choices elected in the at-large system.
It is not necessary, however, and the Court did not rule --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well does that -- does that inference -- finding by inference that you suggest stand -- stand up under a mathematical analysis?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: It has to.
Blacks are 35% --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: -- of the population of -- of Mobile.
They are less than that of the voting age population of Mobile.
I think it is closer to -- to 30% or 32%.
And if they were registered at the same rate as -- as whites they would still be a political minority in the community by a substantial margin.They are not close to being a majority.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How about the Catholics in Mobile, is there anything in this record to show how many there are?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: There -- there was plenty of evidence in the record to show that there was not polarization of electoral processes along religious lines or along ethnic lines in Mobile, Alabama.
That the only discernible polarization from a social standpoint was along the lines of race.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Blacksher, if we just for the moment confine ourselves to the Fourteenth Amendment again, I understand your separate argument on the Voting Rights Act and the Fifteenth Amendment.

I'd like to pursue the thought Mr. Justice Rehnquist and I suggested earlier about -- you would say the same theory would apply to Catholics, a -- or religious or an ethnic group as well as to blacks.
What about a political group such as Republicans?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I was asked that -- that question I believe at the first argument, Justice Stevens, and my reply would be the same.
I -- I believe that -- that political groups probably would be protected.
Although I think there's a difference in that -- as I've -- as I've said before, I think politics is the -- the vehicle or the forum through which we operate the political process.
That it is a -- a volitional choice which party you are in, and that may cause some differences, differences which I simply have not explored and which I don't think the Court needs to at this point.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, do you think --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Certainly --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- if a city has got clear -- if a city -- if the Republicans and the Democrats are segregated by area in a city, do you think a city may draw their -- their electoral districts based on those lines so as to clearly to determine -- predetermine who's going to win?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I believe that the city can draw their district lines anywhere that they fairly choose so long as it cannot be demonstrated that the particular ethnic or political group you're talking about has not -- has been systematically excluded from the political process.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So let's assume that there'd never been a Republican elected in Mobile in history.
I suppose that's true, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Oh, no, they have -- Mobile is growingly Republican.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's -- let's suppose that it -- that it had been, a history like that.
And -- and you -- and it was -- there was proof that it was -- that the at-large system was maintained to maintain the Democratic majority and the Democratic control.
Now, under the Fourteenth Amendment, would -- you would say that you would come out the same way here?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I believe that it's possible to if you can show --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I didn't -- I know it is possible, but how about you?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Well, I believe that -- that we have to refer back to White versus Regester for the realm of possibilities.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, but would you be making this same argument here or wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: As I just said, I may or I may -- I don't know the difference -- whether the difference in political concerns makes the kind of difference that -- that distinguish it from ethnic or religious or in this case racial classifications, and I'm just not prepared to -- to take a final position on that, if it please the Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if the -- it depends a lot I suppose it -- whether you are or not depends on how strong your Fourteenth Amendment argument is as distinguished from your Fifteenth and your Voting Rights Act.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Well, the thrust of my argument today has been that I think that the Voting Rights and -- the Voting Rights Act and Fifteenth Amendment arguments are clearly the strongest because of their Constitutional mandate.
Because -- because we're not dealing with a -- a political theory that we are inventing out of whole cloth, we are dealing with Constitutional commands.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And also I suppose in the Voting Rights Act because you claim it covers effect as well as purpose.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We don't think you have to reach that question if you affirm the findings of purpose below.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, I know -- I know but you wouldn't even need to affirm that, you could assume it if you take the Voting Rights Act.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We assume what, may it please the Court?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That there's a purpose rather than effect.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We do not assume that there's purpose rather than effect.
We -- we think we've proved it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know you do but -- but if we weren't convinced on purpose, you would say, well, nevertheless there is effect.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: We would.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I would like to -- to leave by referring again to White versus Regester because the facts in this case were so much stronger than those in White with respect to showing that there was a systematic denial and abridgement and submergence of the black voting rights and interests in Mobile, Alabama than there were in Dallas and Bexar County --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that -- didn't White against Regester involved legislative districts --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: It was the state --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- representative democracy?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: The state legislature.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not the executive and legislative and administrative --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- government of a municipality, did they?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: But the principle of White --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's -- isn't that an issue, one of the issues here suggested by Mr. Justice Rehnquist's concurring opinion in Wise against Lipscomb?

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That's correct.
We wouldn't --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You haven't -- you haven't talked about that at all.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: I -- I would mention it.
I would say that I think that the issue is foreclosed by some earlier opinions.
And I think Allen versus State Board of Elections, Perkins versus Matthews, City of Petersburg, City of Richmond, Beer against United States, United States versus Sheffield --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I know -- you're -- you're mixing up an awful lot of things.Beer was a -- was a Voting Rights Act case not a Constitutional case.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: They were all -- all of the cases I cited --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: All of those were --

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: -- were Voting Rights Cases --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: All of those and they came under the statute.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Which recognized that dilution was a wrong for which there was a federal remedy (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because the statute covers political subdivisions.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Avery versus Middle -- Midland County extended the one person, one vote principle to the local level --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that was a Constitutional case.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: And that was what Justice Stewart was I think --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: -- getting to.
Where --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: j_u_blacksher
turn.label: Mr. J. U. Blacksher
turn.text: Where is the Constitutional precedent for extending dilution or White versus Regester to the local level?
And that gets back I guess to what I was saying earlier.

If -- how can you extend one person-one vote to the local level and say that it's a -- a more fundamental principle than the right of blacks not to have their voting rights abridged which is what the Constitutional mandate is in the beginning -- in the first place.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Turner.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Turner, before you commence, I would be interested in knowing what groups you think are encompassed by the term "race" in the Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Well, that -- that's a question on which the Court has thus far given us very little guidance.
Certainly the -- the purpose, the original purpose of the Fifteenth Amendment was to secure the franchise for newly freed black citizens.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Clearly.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: So that's clearly covered.
It's also on occasion been applied in other circumstances to other ethnic minorities.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Would you include Mexican-Americans?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I would, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And I think your colleague would include Orientals.
What about Indians?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I think they would be covered as well, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And Puerto Ricans?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: What about Socialists?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I have no opinion about Socialists, Mr. Justice Powell.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well would it -- would it, Mr. Turner, include any national group that was the subject of -- their object of determination of discrimination rather?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I really think, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, that we ought to approach questions under the Fifteenth Amendment as we do in other areas on a case-by-case basis.
And what we have here is a case involving blacks.
What we have in the United Jewish Organization was a case involving Hasidic Jews and --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: -- in each one you're going to be able to make a -- an assessment of the factual situation, you're going to be able to compare the legislative history and the Constitutional history and make a coherent judgment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you -- you had no trouble saying that Hispanic Americans would -- would be included.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: None at all.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And what -- what leads you to be able to answer that question so easily and yet shy away from any expansion into other national origin areas?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Because I think that one of the touchstones that I get out of this Court's opinions on the Fifteenth Amendment is that it is -- is directed towards the protection of the suffrage rights of traditionally discriminated against groups.
And I think that includes Hispanics, includes Puerto Ricans, it may in cases include Asian-Americans.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Could it ever include whites?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Surely, as the -- as the Court at least the majority seemed to say in United Jewish Organization.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How about Mormons?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: That would be a religious group and I know of no basis under the Fifteenth Amendment directly to cover Mormons although if there were compelling circumstances and they were a discriminated against group, it strikes me that the Court might well entertain the argument although I don't know how it would come out.
The one underlying concern that I think many people have about this case is its scope.

There are lots of large elections in this country, there are lots of different minorities, as we have just gone through, and the question I think suggests itself of whether by affirming the decisions below, the Court would be taking a giant step towards requiring Constitutional reform of hundreds of cities.
Now, if I make no other point today, I want to argue that on this record the electoral practices in Mobile are in a special category.
These cases do not present the normal operation of your regular garden variety at-large election system that all of us are familiar with and which have produced competent governments across the land.
Yes, sir?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Turner, you speak for the United States here, for the Department of Justice.

Now, over recent years the Federal Government has engaged in a great many activities, legislative, executive and otherwise to -- to ensure the rights of minorities to have housing in -- in an integrated way with all other people.
Is that not right?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: We have made in my department every effort to enforce the Fair Housing Act which so far we have regarded as a freedom of choice statute.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now if you succeed in that enterprise widely, then district -- or elections won't help very much, will they?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Not if we succeeded but these measure of success is not so great at this point or foreseeable --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well -- well --

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: -- that that can happen.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- not that it is right now, but if you succeed, if your objective is a sound objective, and -- and Congress has decided that it is, how do you reconcile that with the insistence on a program that will furnish an incentive for people of a particular category to live in enclaves, whether they be Indians, Puerto Ricans, Orientals, Spanish surnamed people, whatever?
How do you reconcile these two things?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I -- I think that as long as you have a situation as in Mobile, where at-large systems are used racially to dilute minority votes, there will be no progress away from block voting.
And when minorities are able to elect members of the government, our experience is that the stigma that once attached to race quickly dissolves.
Birmingham is an example that Mr. Rhyne mentioned.
Tomorrow a black councilman, not a private citizen but a councilman is in the runoff for mayor.
While there is no record of the facts there of the participation, the -- his participation in local government certainly was of assistance in getting him into the runoff.

So I think that at this stage in the history, where there are ghettos and where there are separate residences, and the -- and the record here shows that you couldn't divide Mobile into three districts without one of them being majority black, it's that kind of housing segregation we're talking about.
And no effort by my department to -- to enforce the Fair Housing Act is going to change that in the next few years.
The -- so this -- Mobile it seems to me is not a situation like Marion County, Indiana in the Chavis case where blacks just got on the wrong side in elections and therefore lost.
Here, the blacks have formed a political group, the Non-partisan Voters League and repeatedly have attempted to form coalitions with like-minded white voters but has been repeatedly unsuccessful.
My time is very short but I'd like to point out a couple of things to you.
And Mr. Rhyne has spoken about the powers of the League's endorsement.

This endorsement is made on a pink sample ballot and it is true that many candidates seek this support but has not described as how the League has to withhold release of that endorsement, keep it secret until sometimes within hours of the poll operations.
A State Senator Edington, a white Senator, testified that he has 20 years experience in Mobile politics.

He says it has to be held up before the election because those who don't get the endorsement want to get copies and spread them out to other areas in Mobile County to use against the candidates that were endorsed.
The result is that black supported candidates frequently get into the runoff --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there anything in the state law or federal law that -- that would prohibit that process of circulating it in other districts?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: No.

But what we're -- what we're trying to find out, it -- it seems to me, is whether Mobile is a situation like Marion County, Indiana, where blacks were Democrats and they lost elections and they came to this Court complaining that they lost more elections than they should and they didn't have enough representation.
And the Court said, “That's tough because you've made political choices and you had a fair chance.”
Now, if Mobile was like that, we wouldn't be here.
But the two courts below have said it isn't like that and I am trying to point out the basis for their reasoning.

And so that when you get to the runoff election and there's a black supported candidate whose pink endorsement has been made known now, there's no way to hide it any longer and that is where you get what one expert called the "kiss of death."
The record has several examples.
Let me just give you one.
If you turn to page 593 in Volume II of the appendix in the Mobile case, that's No. 77-1844, the numbers are at the bottom --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Page 590 --

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: 593, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: In Volume II.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Volume II.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Volume II.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: The numbers are at the bottom.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: The Volume II, it seems to begin with page 821.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: The numbers are at the bottom, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Oh.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: There was a Mobile person, Mrs. Gerre Koffler, a white resident, who decided to run for the school board in 1972 because she wanted to see if there was some way we could make the April Supreme Court decision work in Mobile, that's your decision in Davis.
She obtained the League's endorsement.
She got into the runoff and if you look at page 593 you will see the kind of ad that came out after the endorsement was made public.

It shows a picture of a -- of a black leader, John LeFlore, it shows the white candidate, it alleges such scurrilous things that she has entertained blacks in her home, she has been seen and photographed in company of blacks, but it also shows the exact vote she got in each black ward --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I gather Gerre Koffler is a female, you call her she.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Yes.
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Has there ever been a woman commissioner?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I am unaware of that, Your Honor.
I'm sure local counsel would be able to enlighten.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are woman a minority or a majority of the voters in Mobile?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I'm not sure whether they're a majority or a minority.
I believe by most accounts they are a slight preponderance.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: District --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of -- of the population generally?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you don't know about the voters in Mobile?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: District elections wouldn't help that situation, would it?
Women don't tend to live in particular enclaves or ghettos.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Not -- not in my experience, no sir.

If you turn to page 595, you'll see a similar ad run in the same runoff election against another white candidate whose black support had been revealed by the primary election, and it is the same story.
The -- the "kiss of death" is right there.
So it's not just this kind of racial voting, there is more in this record.
There's other aspects in Mobile that are unique, is the at-large elected -- in one at-large legislative election, white --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Turner --

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: -- Democrats and Republicans agreed --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: May I ask you a question that always puzzles me in these cases.
The -- I don't know whether these are -- who sponsored these ads but no doubt a -- a group of people who were against having blacks be elected to public office.
Whose intent is really most important here?
I suppose you can always find in a community some very strong anti-black sentiment, maybe in the legislature, maybe in the city council.
What -- what group of people if any should we focus on in the intent issue?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Well, it's a -- it's a very troublesome thing and I think it may depend on which amendment you want to talk about.
Intent is very nebulous especially in a case like this.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: What -- what do you -- what do you understand it to mean or what do you understand the court below to have held on the intent issue?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Okay.

I understand that as in Norwood versus Harrison, where Mississippi since 1940 had maintained a textbook program and then when desegregation of schools came that program mushroomed to provide books to the private schools.
It was the evolution, the changing circumstances that eroded what had been a perfectly proper state purpose into an illegitimate unconstitutional one by the decision of this Court.
So if you're talking about that kind of -- of change, that kind of evolutionary change --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: -- it is very hard to --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Here, we're talking about a refusal to make a change.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And in that -- this kind of case, whose intent should we look at?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Well, it's the same thing in -- in Norwood, I submit.
But here, if you go in the Fourteenth Amendment, I say you look at the legislative intent.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: The state legislature?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: The state legislature.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And each of these pamphlets here are not relevant on that intent issue.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: No.
Now, if (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Does it have any relevance at all to the case?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: If you have -- if you go on the Fifteenth Amendment cases, Your Honor.
We have outlined in the brief how this Court's precedents, especially Terry versus Adams, have held that by a state adopting --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Let me put the question this way.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: -- private purposeful discrimination --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Let me put the question this way.

If it's the legislative intent that's controlling, supposing everybody in Mobile wanted to have blacks fairly represented and was giving them excellent services and were promptly prosecuting people who burned crosses and everything was going along fine.
But you had the majority of the state legislature who've said, “We don't want any blacks in the government in Mobile.”
Would it be the same case?

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: I'm not sure, certainly not under the Fifteenth Amendment because it is our submission that under the Fifteenth Amendment that what the -- that there certainly state involvement in running elections and in running at-large elections in Mobile, and there certainly is private discrimination, just like there was in the Jaybird Club.
And by the state magnifying and making use and making effective that private discrimination, it's the same principle as Terry versus Adams that would apply.
So you use private discrimination that's implemented by state procedures.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Turner.

turn.speaker: james_p_turner
turn.label: Mr. James P. Turner
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Rhyne.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: If the Court please, I only have two comments and then, unless the Court has some questions, I have no further argument.
I'm really amazed that the government of the United States would try to use a School Board Race exhibit on 593 and a County Commission race on 595 against the city.
I pointed out in my argument that the two are entirely different and I think that this shows how weak their case is if they would stoop that low.
Now, I would be glad to answer any questions the Court has, but my time is just about up and --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, those exhibits, Mr. Rhyne, do show that apparently there's some evidence that there was block voting on racial lines there, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I suppose if there's block voting on the school board or on the county election, it's reasonable to infer that there'd be block voting on the --

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: But -- but the --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: -- on the other kinds of (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: -- the school board is county-wide and the county is county-wide.
It's an entirely different constituency, as Mr. Alexander pointed out in the record, from the constituency in the city.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I'm not --

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: And so to try to --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: There's some overlap, isn't there?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Oh, there's some overlap, sure.
I wouldn't -- I wouldn't deny that for one minute.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Would you challenge the District Court finding that there was racial block voting in this -- within the jurisdiction we're talking about?

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: I would say I do.
It's -- it's lessening, according to expert Boyles and that more and more throughout the South as well as in Mobile, race is not a factor in elections.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Whoever put out these pamphlets apparently thought it was.

turn.speaker: charles_s_rhyne
turn.label: Mr. Charles S. Rhyne
turn.text: Well, I think that those pamphlets were used in a different race, for a different purposes and had nothing to do with the city and that's my own point about it.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Rhyne.
Mr. Allen, you may proceed --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: May it please the Court.
This case concerns the legality of the way the commissioners, the school commissioners of Mobile County are elected.
Mobile County encompasses the City of Mobile and a rather large surrounding area which includes some other smaller cities.
Overall, the population of the county is divided racially in about the same proportions as the city.
Blacks make up 32% of the county's population and I think 24% of its voters.
Mobile County's school system was the first to be established in Alabama in 1826, seven years after statehood.

Since that time probably, and at least since 1836, when a new statute governing the school system was enacted, the members of the governing body of the school system have been elected from the county at large.
The current statute under which they have been elected, it was enacted in 1919, provides for the at-large election of five commissioners.
They are elected in partisan elections held in even numbered years for six-year staggered terms.
As a board, the commissioners are responsible for the overall direction and management of the Mobile County schools.
They hire a superintendent who is responsible under their direction for the day-to-day management.

Now, certain salient points appear from the findings below and the -- or the undisputed evidence of record concerning the school board's elections and their relation to the black population of the county.
First, the system of at-large elections for Mobile County school board members was not created for any racially discriminatory reasons.
As I have already indicated the system has deep roots in the history of Alabama and of Mobile in particular.
It was first established in 1836, no later, at a time when blacks did not vote and the last reestablished in 1919 at a time when blacks were still effectively disfranchised.

Second, the second salient point notwithstanding the history of racial discrimination in Alabama and Mobile, there are today no barriers, no barriers formal or informal to black participation in Mobile County's political process.
Blacks are free to register and vote and they do vote nearly in proportion to their proportion of the voting age population.
Their votes are sought for.
The only significant candidate endorsing body that appears to operate county-wide in Mobile County is what you have heard about, that's the Non-partisan Voters League.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that the same league that we heard --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.
That --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- about in the other case?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: It operates in the county --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
