turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And city -- the city (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: -- and city as well, yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not just two organizations.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: No, the same organization.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: With the same name.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: That they're predominantly a black group.

And there's no comparable white group, there's no backstage or -- or even front-stage slating organizations of the kind the Court may have been concerned with in some other cases, no slating really in that sense.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything in -- in your record that shows who pays for all of this advertising, their political stuff?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: This -- in my -- I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything in the record that shows who pays for these advertisements and other things that normally help in political campaigns?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: There is not, Your Honor.
One can infer that the advertisements were paid for by the candidate running against the candidate who is -- who is disfavored in those ads, if that's what Your Honor means.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, I think I know enough about politics that money doesn't come out of the clear blue sky.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.
I -- there is -- there is no evident -- record evidence about the sources --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And doesn't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: -- of campaign funds.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So I am still in the same place.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.
But in any event, in that regard, anyone is free to run for office and -- and the fact is that a school board campaign does not cost very much.
Up until very recently -- up until very recently, the school board members have not been paid at all and they're still paid rather nominally.
So a typical campaign budget runs no more than $2,000, $3,000, $5,000, it's according to the record.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How many members of the school board?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: There are five members.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And are they elected to staggered terms?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: They are elected for six-year staggered terms, they're two, two, and one system.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it a -- is it a per diem compensation they get or --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: It -- it is a per -- per meeting kind --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Per meeting.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: -- of compensation now.
Yes, yes, yes.
Now, the third salient point, and I have to acknowledge this on the record of this case, whatever may be the case in the city's case, there does appear to be racial polarization in voting.
Four black candidates ran in the Democratic Primary for the school board between 1962 and 1974.
Each of them reached the runoff election, although each was a first-time candidate for public office.
Each was defeated in a runoff against a white opponent.

Now, on the basis substantially of what I've recited plus a few more rather tangential items, the District Court concluded that the at-large manner of electing Mobile County school commissioners violates the Fourteenth and perhaps the Fifteenth Amendments.
The District Court made its analysis of this issue within the framework of the so-called Zimmer factors, factors that the Court of Appeals had professed to distill from this Court's opinions.

The Court of Appeals performed that distillation in a case called Zimmer against McKeithen before Washington against Davis was decided, and they were obviously -- the Zimmer factors were intended to measure the discriminatory effects of an -- of an at-large system.
The District Court's ultimate conclusion in this case was that the plaintiffs had met their burden by showing an aggregate of the factors catalogued in Zimmer.
The Court of Appeals affirmed in a very short per curiam opinion without hearing argument and referring merely to a prior decision in the City of Mobile's case.
The District Court's remedy for the constitutional violation it found was to create five districts, two of which are preponderantly black in population.

The Court of Appeals also affirmed this remedy, the judgment was not stayed, elections were held and the two predominantly black districts in 1978, two black candidates were elected to the board and now sit.
I am not going to dwell this morning on the District Court's Zimmer analysis in what we conceive to be its flaws which are thoroughly explored in our briefs.

If the plaintiffs continue to defend that analysis either as it was actually engaged in by the District Court or as it was transmuted by the Court of Appeals in other cases into the equivalent of a finding of purpose rather than effect, they do so I think very faintly at this stage.

What the plaintiffs essentially rely on in this Court is something different, a passage, one passage of the District Court's opinion that's wholly removed from the analysis on which it purported to base its opinion.
That's a passage in which the Court does indeed talk about a present purpose to discriminate.
Now let me take up the -- the District Court's opinion.
It -- it first made findings of fact arranged under each of the Zimmer headings.
These are at pages 9 to 22 of the appendix.
And then it turned to the conclusions of law.

The passage on which the plaintiffs rely appears in a section of the conclusions of law where the Court was dressed -- addressing itself for nine pages to the impact of Washington against Davis in vote dilution cases.
It asked whether Washington against Davis was dispositive of this case so as to preclude application of the Zimmer factors.
Now, at page 34 it -- it made a comment about the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Page 34 of what?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Of the -- of our appendix, 34A of the appendix.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: It talked about a present purpose to dilute the black vote.
Now, I submit that that is not a finding of a present purpose to discriminate.

Plaintiffs have tried to make of it a finding, have talked even about the two court rules and urged deference to that finding, but it isn't a finding, isn't even really a legal conclusion, the sort of conjecture on the part of the District Court at the best and really more likely the statement of a -- of a discarded alternative legal theory for deciding the case.

What the -- because what the Court finally says down near the bottom of page 34 is that more basic and fundamental than any of the above approaches is that, and then it goes on and I suggest says that Washington against Davis established no new purpose test so far as voting dilution cases are concerned.
And that was the answer to the question that it posed itself at the beginning of this part of its opinion and --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Allen, to -- taking that page of the appendix to which you're addressing, the last sentence in the paragraph in the middle of the page, the Court says there is a "current" condition of dilution of the black vote resulting from intentional state legislative inaction which is as effectual as the intentional state action referred to in Keyes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: May I interrupt to say I'm -- I'm lost.
I have 34B --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- but I -- of what?
Of the appendix --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: We have the -- the city's appendix, I'm sorry, Your Honor, the -- our appendix.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 34A of the appendix?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: 34A of the appendix.
I'm very sorry.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And it begins at the top of the page, "This is not to say," quoting?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Alright.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Wouldn't -- wouldn't you at least concede that that is a finding of intentional state legislative inaction?
Not -- you may feel that is not the same thing as -- as intentional action.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I -- sir -- I suggest, Your Honor, what I -- what I was -- the point I sought to make was that I do not consider that a -- I do consider it indeed.
It is a statement of whatever is said there.
It is not I suggest a finding in any -- in any customary sense of that.
He'd made his findings of fact elsewhere and -- and he really had not addressed himself at -- at any length to what might underlie a -- a finding of a -- in -- current intentional state inaction.

But I will go on and say that we can suppose -- we can suppose that this passage really did mean to conclude far more than it -- than it seems to have on its -- on -- on its face, that the at-large elections involves a present purpose to discriminate through state inaction.
Now -- now the -- the further question is what record facts are there that might support such a conclusion.

The Court mentioned one specific fact on the preceding page and there it said -- and these are its words approximately, whenever a redistricting bill of any type is proposed by a member of the Mobile County legislative delegation, a major concern is centered around how many if any blacks would be elected.
He does say that.

Now, the fact is that in spite of that concern -- in spite of that concern, or perhaps even because of it, the legislature in 1975 did enact districting legislation for the Mobile County school system.
That legislation was voided on the suit of the school board because of a defect in notice that rendered it invalid under the state constitution.
Now, the -- the plaintiffs met to seek to make a great deal of this invalidation.
I think what they would have this Court rule is that the districting legislation and its invalidation somehow constitute evidence of a present purpose to discriminate.
The least that can be said in response to that, Your Honors, is that the District Court did not so treat it and made no such finding.
And I would suggest further that the federal judicial inquiry that might even yield such a finding would be an undertaking of extreme delicacy.
I submit that this Court should not be asked to make the sort of judgment on the Alabama legislature that appellees state or imply on the basis of nothing more than what appears in this record.

So when the specifics are out of the way that the District Court cited and if we forget the 1975 enactment that on its face looks the other way, what we have at the very most, at the very most is state legislative inaction that maintains a non-racially motivated at-large voting system and an awareness on the part of at least some legislators of the disparate racial effects of that system.

Now, I submit that to make a finding or to draw a conclusion of a present purpose to discriminate on the basis of this perpetuation arguably of discriminatory effects through inaction is exactly -- is exactly what this Court rejected last term in Personnel Administrator against Feeney, and indeed in the Feeney case there was more than mere inaction.

The Massachusetts Veterans Preference law had been amended from time to time and effectively reenacted, and the Court did not blink at saying that there must have been full awareness on the part of the general court that the legislation -- that the legislation was keeping a disproportionate number of women out of the higher levels of the civil service.
But that wasn't enough.
That wasn't enough.
To have made it enough would have undermined the rule of constitutional law with which the Court began its analysis in Feeney.

And that rule stated, even in the paradigm case of race, that is what the Court said, even if a neutral law has a disproportionately adverse effect, it is unconstitutional under the Equal Protection Clause only if that impact can be traced to a discriminatory purpose.
Now, let me stop there for a moment and just say a word about the Fifteenth Amendment.
The Court of Appeals held in the companion cases, one doesn't know what the Court meant to hold in our case because its -- its opinion is not at all revealing.

But in the companion cases, the Court of Appeals held that the Fifteenth Amendment imposes the same purpose requirement, and we have urged in our briefs -- I will not -- I will not expand upon the points now but I think they're adequately made there that the Court of Appeals was quite right that -- that one does not escape the problem that is posed under the Fourteenth Amendment in this case by turning to the Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Assuming there were a private cause of action in the Voting Rights Act, what do you say about the Voting Rights Act?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I would say -- I was just about to turn to that, Your Honor, and I would say further two things under the Voting Rights Act.
One, the argument that's made here is made most belatedly.
To be sure -- to be sure, the Voting Rights Act has been in the case.
Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act has been in the case from the beginning.
It has never been suggested until we reached this Court that it might have a different content from the -- from the Fifteenth Amendment.

And what the government says in its amicus brief about Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, seems to me the capsule, what it is and why it also does not -- does not offer a way out of -- of what may be the problem posed by this case.
In a footnote on page 84 of its brief, the government says Section 2 represents Congress' rearticulation of the Fifteenth Amendment.
And that is what it amounts to.
The -- that the standards -- it is not Section 5.
It does not read the same way as Section 5.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but the government doesn't think necessarily that purpose is essential in the Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: The government does --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you're not -- you're not really making much of a point.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Oh, I understand that but -- but I was -- independently of what the government says, we believe that -- that the legislative history does indeed show that all --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let me ask you -- let me -- let me go at this in -- in two --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- two steps.
One, do you think the argument is available in this Court by an appellee that the Voting Rights Act is an issue here and should be disposed of first?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that the Voting Rights Act covers effect as well as purpose?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I -- I will answer the first part of the question.
I say I think the issue is here.
Whether the Court would wish to remand for development of the point is a separate subject (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the issue is fairly -- the issue of the Voting Rights Act is fairly here, you think?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How about the issue of the Voting Rights Act covering effect as well as purpose?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Oh, do I think that is a legitimate issue here?
I think yes.
I think that is all the more reason for -- for a remand were the Court not to think that on its face Section 2 is a mere restatement of the Fifteenth Amendment, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And do you think that, as you understand our cases, we should dealing with the Voting Rights Act first --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- in any opinion that we write in this case --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Because I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- at least -- at least either -- either on -- on the merits or at least put the issue aside?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I think -- I think it would be fair to put the -- the issue aside.

I think it would also be fair, I mean, I happen to believe on the merits that -- that the Voting Acts -- Voting Act meaning issue is not -- is not a difficult one and that -- that it does come down to meaning the same thing as whatever Your Honors think the Fifteenth Amendment means.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is -- is your act -- is your response to Justice White's question predicated in -- in any way on an assumption that there is or is not a private cause of action under --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I believe, if he asked me to make that assumption.
That is the first obstacle --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I'm sorry, I misunderstood.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: -- that has to be hurdled in getting to Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, to be sure, and we have -- we have urged in the -- in our reply brief at some length why it should not be read as creating a private cause of action, never been so read to this time that I'm aware of.
Let me return -- let me return to Feeney and make one final point in -- in respect to that -- that opinion as it bears on our case.
The Court there spoke of the impact of veterans' preference on women as essentially an unavoidable consequence of a legislative policy that has always been deemed to be legitimate.

So far as the legitimacy of state policy is concerned, if veterans' preference is a legitimate legislative policy then surely the policy of at-large municipal elections, the policy that antedates the Constitution still prevails in hundreds, even scores of communities throughout the country, is a legitimate policy.

And as for the inevitability of the adverse consequences of pursuing the policy, one can hope -- one can hope that the unfortunate consequences of at-large elections are not unavoidable or inevitable --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it you -- I take it as -- pretty fairly your position that a municipal at-large election or a -- for the purposes of state legislatures, a -- say, a county-wide at-large election or -- or a multi-number district, electoral district for the election of, say, 10 state representatives, neither of those arrangements at-large is -- is shown to be unconstitutional if you have also a very clear proof of voting on racial lines (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Even the -- I mean, even though one has that proof --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even though -- let's say anybody in his right mind would say yes, there's pretty clearly racial lines here.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Even though --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You don't -- putting those two together, it doesn't -- equals --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Does not add up to the constitutional or statutory violation that that -- on which this case is based.
Yes, that is exactly Your Honor -- our point, Your Honor.
We think -- we believe that that -- that is the beginning point of analysis.
The problem arises, somebody gets to exercise and brings a lawsuit when he -- when he sees an at-large system of elections and what can be termed racial -- racially polarized or block voting.

The inquiry proceeds from that point, the inquiry proceeds from that point, it doesn't end there, and we -- our concern here is that the -- that we think the District Court essentially ended its inquiry there.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Allen, let's proceed one step further beside -- beyond the assumptions Mr. Justice White made.
Assume the record does demonstrate there's an appropriate finding of a present intent to maintain the system in order to prevent black participation in the school board.
Would that constitute a constitutional violation when the original rule was lawful when adopted?What is your view on that?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I -- all I can say in answer to that, Your -- Your Honor, is that if there were indeed the basis for and the kind of finding that I would hope this Court would insist upon, the kind of record that this -- I hope this Court would insist upon to find a present intent of the -- of a legislature, then I would have a hard time distinguishing that case from the case in which the -- the statute added in its inception was racially discriminatory.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
Mr. Schnapper.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

Before turning to the substantive issues presented by the case, I think it might be useful to lay out some of the procedural problems about the way the Court will choose to address the variety of issues presented here.
Some of them have come up before, some of them have not.
One issue which Mr. Allen raised and which has been raised by earlier questions is -- is whether or not to deal with the statutory question that is I think unquestionably presented by the case.
The Court has for many years maintained a policy which it has attempted to persuade the lower courts to follow of deciding statutory issues first and only reaching constitutional issues if necessary.
As this case and Beazer and Bakke all illustrate the lower courts have not been assiduous in attending to that rule.
And the -- the question before the Court is -- is how the Court is to act when the lower court has not followed your preferred procedure.
I think that there are three options, one of which should not be taken.
The one that should not be taken is the -- is the option taken in Arlington Heights, which is to decide the constitutional question and remand for decision on the statutory question.

As you may remember, after ruling for the defendants on the constitutional question in that case that an opinion which provoked some dissents and made a lot of law that may or may not -- had not been necessary, on remand the District Court of Appeals reached the statutory issue ruled for the plaintiff and this Court denied search.
So that an entire opinion with all its ramifications and we deal with many of them today was unnecessary.

I think that -- that following that course would be unwise not only because it leads you into deciding unnecessary issues but because it doesn't -- I would lead the Courts of Appeals by example and that was not the kind of example I think you wanted to give them.

And I think the two options you have are, first, and I think this is probably the proper option to do what you did in Bakke, to decide the statutory issue first, reach the constitutional issue if necessary.
Or you could wipe the whole case out and send it back and tell the Court of Appeals to do it right the first time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of course, you -- your first option which you say you prefer is going to lead to some undesirable practices, too, on the part of people who've lost on a constitutional question in a lower court because they can just look through the statute books and if they can find a statute that they say, “Gee, the others I might have won on this statute”, therefore it was unnecessary to reach the constitutional question, they'll have a built-in argument for at least to a remand.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I -- I think they've got to look through a different volume.
They've got to look through the appendix and take a look at the complaint.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: If it's in the complaint that's one thing.
I would --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but you don't have to --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I would be listing --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Under notice pleading under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, you don't have to state the statute you rely on, all you have to do is plead alleged facts sufficient to support a claim for relief.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, the -- the practice of this Court has generally not been to permit litigants to raise issues which in no way have been raised below.

So I think -- I think it would be perfectly proper and I think consistent with the past practices of the Court that if a litigant wanted to raise a statutory issue which had in no way been raised by the complaint or briefs below, to preclude them from -- from doing that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you don't go so far as to say that the parties must reach -- raise a possible statutory issue along with a constitutional issue?
I suppose --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I would (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- the parties constructed their case just as a constitutional case, if they want to, can't they?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I would think that would be terribly unwise and I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it may be unwise but they -- but they may.

But I -- it may be -- I suppose your answer might be that even if they do, perhaps here the Court would have, if it's to come -- they come from federal courts, you -- I suppose this Court would have the power to insert another issue into it.
But you wouldn't say it was error for lower courts to decide the constitutional issue if the parties had never raised anything but the constitutional issue.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I -- I would say it was an error on the part of the Court of Appeals to have done that.
I think it would be entirely within the discretion of the Court to refuse to entertain a new statutory claim for the -- in the first instance here.

On the other hand, quite frankly, there have been cases where you've chosen to entertain new statutory issues for reasons having to do with subsequent developments and -- and also some suggest -- I wouldn't want -- I wouldn't want to suggest that you lock yourself into a ritual that you'll never do that.
I think you've got -- you ought to retain the power to go either way.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if in Arlington Heights the defendants there had said we -- we simply are -- want a decision on the constitutional question, we're willing to assume the complaint states a claim for relief under the federal statute and all we want to litigate is a constitutional question, what should the District Court --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, it depends -- then I would deny cert.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Because it was a defendant's cert petition.
They'd won below, and you can't file -- at least I have not taken the filing (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what should the District -- what should the District Court have done in deciding the thing in the first instance?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, if the defendants had wanted to come in and concede the existence of a private -- of a statutory claim and won and asked for a decision on the constitutional claim, I assume the District Court would have accepted their concession, ruled for the plaintiffs, and that would have been the end of it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So that it -- it could not then go to the constitutional case?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I can't imagine why a district judge facing a concession of liability under statute would decide a constitutional issue as well.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if -- what if the defendant say, “Let's assume for the sake of argument, we don't concede but we -- we think the most important thing here is the constitutional question”?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I -- just -- no district judge it seems to me would be -- would act properly to let the -- the defendant control the order of decisions and to ignore the policies of this Court to decide statutory issues first.
That's the rule from the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) but there are -- I think there's a -- a lot of district judges that don't.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I think there are, too, and there are some Courts of Appeals judges who don't and that's -- and that it is from that point that I began my suggestion that you deal with this the way you wanted the -- the Court of Appeals and the District Court to deal with it and that is to decide the -- the statutory issue first.

The -- the second problem pertains to something quite related to this and that is the question of whether new issues can be raised for the first time here on appeal and we've got two things that seem to be in that posture.
The first one is the question of whether or not White against Regester apply -- in the doctrine therein applies to municipal governments.
This case is in precisely the same posture as Wise against Lipscomb.
It was never raised below in the District Court or the Court of Appeals.
The policy of this Court is not to permit things to be raised at the last moment and -- and we think you should adhere to that.
On my reading of the record, the same thing is true about whether or not there is a private cause of action under Section 2.

As you recall, with the exception of Mr. Justice Stewart, most members of the Court were of the view in Bakke that that issue not having been raised below could not be raised in that particular case at the first instance here.

And we think that the question of whether there's a private cause of action under the Voting Rights Act is in that posture -- in the same posture that the private cause of action under Title 6 was in Bakke.

Now, I -- I say that without meaning to signal any lack of confidence in our argument that there is a private cause of action, but again as a procedural matter the Court has practices which would be applicable to the -- to dealing with it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, wait a minute.
I -- I don't understand what you're saying.
First of all, I didn't understand the reference to me.I think it was intended to be referenced to Justice White but that's neither here nor there in the Bakke case.
What -- what I don't understand here is -- is what you've just told us about the -- whether or not the private right of action under Title II, Section 2 exists.
As I understand it, the District Court in this case didn't rest at all on the statute.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Right, just like the trial court in Bakke didn't rest on the statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.
And the Court of Appeals relegated the issue to a footnote, is that also correct?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And what did the footnote say?
The (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) -- as I recall, they -- they didn't think a whole lot of the argument but there's a -- as I remember, there was a companion case --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, then one of the reasons (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) explain why they didn't want to reach the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)whole a lot of the argument was, they might have thought offhand, my golly, there's no private right of action under Section 2.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I don't think you could read that into it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I -- I think -- I'm trying to give you an agenda of the problems in the case and that's one of the issues --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: -- you're going to have to -- to sort out.
I think --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, certainly Section 2 is not dispositive and couldn't be here if there is no private right of action under Section 2.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't that true?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: And if --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Yes, that's right.
That's right.
There's no question about that.
Third, there's a -- there's a problem raised in both of the cases here about what we referred to loosely as the two-court rule.
For -- with regard to our particular cases, I think particularly Justice Stevens' questions have pointed out, we maintain that there is a finding of intentional discrimination.
And Mr. Allen takes the position that if there is such a finding it isn't justified on this record.
If the Court were sitting nisi prius or you were righting a Circuit, of course we would be in a very different posture than we're in now.
But the normal practice of this Court and the salutary practice of that is not to get into factual issues of that sort when they've been resolved by the lower courts.
The factual record on which the District Court finding is based is much more substantial than Mr. Allen suggests.
There was first direct testimony by members of the legislature as to the motives of the legislature in dealing with redistricting legislation.

There was a long history of racial discrimination in Alabama including a number of cases in which multi-member districting plans adopted by the state legislature had been held by federal courts in other cases to have been racially motivated.
And the discriminatory impact of this system on blacks was not only -- is not only pronounced, it was known to everybody in the state and to the school board at the time.

So that this case presents all the kinds of evidence which Arlington Heights suggested were -- were relevant to this sort of inquiry and we think the District judge had no choice but to reach the conclusion that he did.

Finally, there is a -- there's a problem here that really is -- fairly characterizes the problem of stare decisis and it goes particularly to -- to whether White is -- White against Regester is good law.
The briefs deal with this in somewhat greater length and the arguments have until now.
I think the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which do you mean, still in existence or good?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Excuse me?
Still in existence or --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which do you mean, still in existence?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, I -- I think it's both of those things.
The -- as we've noted in our brief, White against Regester was based on a series of decisions before then.
It's been cited with approval in half a dozen decisions since White, some of them after Washington against Davis.
White itself was a unanimous decision and a decision only six years ago.
And we think the Court should not entertain a general practice of -- of reopening recent constitutional decisions and -- and this one we suggest was in an -- in any event quite properly decided.
We also note that the argument against for overturning White is really two legs.
One of them is that Washington against Davis has -- has somehow rather changed the underlying law in this area.

We've suggested in our briefs that Washington against Davis and -- and White against Regester deal with two different branches of equal protection law that Washington against Davis is concerned with the branch of equal protection law forbidding racial classifications whereas White against Regester is part of the Reynolds against Sims branch of equal protection law concerning special protections for particularly important and fundamental rights.
The other basis of the attack on White, and one which I think has been recurrent in the questions before the Court today, is whether White makes any sense.

And -- and I think our arguments about wouldn't all this go away if blacks lived everywhere and can't blacks be elected in Los Angeles and the like, and all of which I think on the merits are -- are unpersuasive.
In the final analysis, there are arguments that White against Regester was wrongly decided.
And -- and we think that the Court ought not be entertaining that.
I think we -- you should start with White against Regester, enforce it and we think it would be dispositive to this litigation.
I'd like to turn to -- on other issues that arose earlier.
When we were here in the spring, Mr. Justice Rehnquist asked whether in -- well, he raised the following question, we were discussing apparently inconsistent statements about the Voting Rights Act.
Attorney General Katzenbach was quoted by our side as -- as stating that Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act encompassed the purpose or effect standard.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist noted that Senator Dirksen had made a remark about Section 2 almost meaning the same thing as -- as the Fifteenth Amendment.
And I'd like to return to that subject because I think it's important particularly in view of my position that the statutory issue ought to be decided first.

If you will revert to the Dirksen quote, you'll notice that it doesn't happen on the floor of the Senate, it happens during a hearing, indeed the very hearing, almost at the very hour when Katzenbach testified.
Dirksen was one of the members of the Senate Judiciary Committee and was according to the transcript, in the room at the beginning of the hearing.
Dirksen sat there while Katzenbach said Section 2 means purpose or effect.
A few pages later, Senator Dirksen says the Fifteenth Amend -- Section 2 means almost the same thing as the Fifteenth Amendment.
Now, either those people just -- one has to try to reconcile those statements and of course one could reconcile them by accepting our view of the Fifteenth Amendment.

But I think that -- that the government's footnote and Justice Stevens' opinion in Bakke suggest a more sensible resolution of it which is to say that those two statements were regarded by their spokesmen as -- as consistent with one another.
Because Congress at that point in time regarded Section 2 in -- as incorporating the purpose or effect standard which they thought was in the Fifteenth Amendment.

And there's a passage in -- Justice Stevens, in your opinion in Bakke which describes Title VI in the same kind of way, but -- but suggests that Title VI has independent force and it doesn't merely incorporate whatever the Fourteenth Amendment should be held to mean by this Court, without wanting to get it -- reopen the particular issues that were involved in Bakke.
I think that method of analysis, however persuasive, run persuasive in Bakke is the correct method of analysis here.
The second thing that -- that comes out when you reread that passage is the context in which it was made.
As you will doubtless recall, one of the primary arguments that was made against the Voting Rights Act was that it was regional in nature.
That it only -- that it singled out a group of southern states for treatment different than the treatment of -- that was being afforded to the rest of the country.

Senator Dirksen, in -- in making that remark about Section 2, makes it -- in the context of a paragraph in which he says look at Section 2, Section 2 covers Texas, as you recall, Texas was the big bone of contention because the President was from Texas and it wasn't (Inaudible)
Section 2 covers Texas, so that -- so Texas is covered by the Voting Rights Act, too.
Now, if -- if Section 2 is merely the Fifteenth Amendment in a purposes standard, then that statement makes no sense at all But, if it --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Fifteenth Amendment covers Texas.
What do you mean by that?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: If -- the dispute was about whether the -- why the Voting Rights Act --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Section 2 covers all -- each of the 50 states and so does the Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Yes, sir.
But the -- the criticism that was being made about the Voting Rights Act was that Section 5 didn't apply to all states.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: And in response to that, Dirksen said, “Oh, yes, but Section 2 does so the Act applies all over.”
Now, if Section 2 had no substantive force at all, if it had a different standard than Section 5, a lower standard, the only purpose would give you a cause of action.
Then it wasn't a very -- and that was the same standard as the Fifteenth Amendment, than to say Section 2 covers Texas so the Act applies there was rather -- is rather unpersuasive because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's true --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: -- Section 2 wasn't --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's true that Section 2 covers every state, whatever it means.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: But it didn't make sense as an argument unless it meant some -- it meant the same --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the Fifteenth Amendment covers every state, whatever it means.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: But as an argument to convince other members of the committee --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It was a little rhetoric perhaps.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Well, as rhetoric to convince other members of the committee that -- that the Act was -- was equally applicable to all states, that only makes sense if the substantive meaning of Section 2 was the same as the substantive meaning of the provisions which applied to the southern states.
And as we've noted in our brief, the history of the Voting Rights Act reflects great sensitivity on the part of the Court to the possibility of a regional rule.

We don't think that it was the intent of Congress except in the very narrow area which we have noted, having to do with literacy tests, to create a situation in which the same sort of districting system would be illegal in Prince Edward County, Virginia and legal in Prince George's County, Maryland.
And we don't think Congress should've presumed to have made that kind of distinction unless it's crystal clear that it did.
So that we -- that we find the -- the Dirksen statement consistent with the Katzenbach statement and with our view of the law.
In addition -- well, Justice Stevens, you asked earlier what the relevance of intent was and it's a rather complicated problem which I'd like to deal with very -- very briefly.
It's complicated because it's relevant to a -- to a whole host of issues.
This is a case that presents --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: To throw another question at you at the same time while you're --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think intent was an essential part of the holding in White against Regester?
Do you think the Court relied there on impact or --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Absolutely not.
It was entirely irrelevant.
As we've laid out in our brief, this Court has three times described the rule in White as a rule that means -- that is -- in these terms, designedly or otherwise diluting the block vote.
White -- Whitcomb began with a statement that it was conceded that there was no discriminatory intent and then went on to write for four or five pages.
So I think it is crystal clear that intent was no part of the White against Regester holding.

With regard to the relevance of intent here, this is a case as we noted in the spring that raises five or six different legal theories and intent is of different relevance to the -- to various of them.

With regard to our claim that this election system is intentionally maintained to prevent the election of blacks, the relevant intent -- discriminatory intent is the intent of the people who make laws.

I phrase it that way because the -- the practical political control of the legislative process is rather complicated, involves primarily the legislative delegation to a significant extent, in this case the school board itself.
But -- and so I don't phrase it in terms of the legislature, but I think that's consistent with the way you were phrasing the question earlier.

With regard to our claim under White against Regester, it is our position that -- that racial discrimination by the elected officials is of some relevance to proving the cause of action which we think we've proved here.
We don't think it is of much importance as -- as Zimmer against McKeithen does.

We think that racial discrimination by the all-white elected government tends to confirm our claim that they are essentially elected solely by the whites and are solely responsive to the whites in town.

With regard to our Fifteenth Amendment claim, in -- in arguing that the Fifteenth Amendment covers discriminatory effect, we've resorted in particular to the legislative history of the Fifteenth Amendment, pointing out that the framers of that amendment were concerned to protect not the right of blacks to put X's on pieces of paper but to give blacks a right that would allow them to protect themselves from racial discrimination by state and local governments, particularly at the end of reconstruction which everybody by 1869 or 1870 knew was inevitable.

If -- if we are correct in -- in that construction of the Fifteenth Amendment, then it would -- it would demonstrate the -- the particular relevance of the effect meaning of the Fifteenth Amendment that the right to vote such as it exists in Mobile for blacks is clearly not carrying out the effect of Congress, the intent of Congress.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that view of the Fifteenth Amendment consistent with the -- the Court opinion in Gomillion against Lightfoot?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I think Gomillion is fairly described as opaque.

One must recall that at the time of Gomillion there were decisions of this Court, a line of decisions which continued up until Palmer against Thompson and O'Brien against United States, which suggested that -- that an inquiry into the intent of legislature was impermissible.

So that as of the date of Gomillion, opinions were being phrased rather carefully so they didn't exactly find intent and they didn't exactly find purpose, they were just sort of outraged and said you couldn't do it --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, but wasn't --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: -- and I think Gomillion is in that posture.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Wasn't there a great deal of emphasis in the Gomillion opinion, which I have not read recently, upon the fact that this could -- this particular -- this -- the city boundaries in that case could only here been attributable to an intent to disenfranchise non --

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I -- I couldn't read --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- non-whites?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: -- Gomillion in -- in that way.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You do not?

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: I don't read Gomillion in that way.
I mean I -- I think that was the intent involved, but I think that the -- the opinion is -- is phrased to avoid making that kind of statement.
It would've -- at the time have been quite arguably improper to make -- to put that kind of conclusion of law in an opinion.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your time has expired now, Mr. Schnapper.

turn.speaker: eric_schnapper
turn.label: Mr. Eric Schnapper
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Allen, I think we can hear you out before we rise for lunch.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Thank you Your Honor.
I think I only have one point and -- and that is that I hope it is not we who are being accused of -- of thinking that White against Regester represents something less than good law.
The -- the fact is that the opening of the analysis in White against Regester begins this way.
We have entertained claims that multi-member districts are being used invidiously to cancel out or minimize the voting strengths of racial groups.
To sustain such proof, it is not enough that the racial group has not had legislative seats in proportion to its voting potential.

The plaintiffs' burden, paraphrasing now, is to produce evidence that would support findings that the political processes leading to nomination and election are not equally open to participation by the groups in question.
And that we submit is what was lacking from the proofs offered in the -- in the county or the -- the school district's case here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think that's equivalent to purpose or not?

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Excuse me?

I think it -- I think that what was -- that the circumstances of which that -- that general rule was applied in White against Regester was the equivalent of a purpose to exclude from participation, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it from what you answered me before or an answer to someone, when you were up before, that if -- if it were satisfactorily shown that a multi-member district was adopted or that if it was refused to dissolve it for the purpose of maintaining the effects of racial block voting that you would have a tough time defending --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: I would have a -- I would have a tough time -- we'd -- we have -- I should say this much about White against Regester.
We have indeed urged although that the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because all -- you can have all the legislative purpose you want but if -- if the racial block voting suddenly falls apart and they start voting on the merits --

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: Then you have not affected --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_allen
turn.label: Mr. William H. Allen
turn.text: -- the discrimination.
That is quite -- that's quite true.
One would have to find that.
One would have to find that the -- that the group claiming to be disadvantaged was indeed disadvantaged, to be sure.
But where all one has -- where all one has is the block voting and a -- and a statute neutral in its inception then it is our position that that is what is not enough.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
